job_title: IT Project Manager in Eden Prairie, MN
pros:
I will preface this review with a statement you need to heed when reading this review as well as any reviews for this company -- "It depends on your area."  

This is a GIGANTIC company and YMMV depending on your group. Keep that in mind when reading.

Anyway, I've been here only 6 months, but I think I have enough of a feel for Optum to write a review.

The positives:
Great work/life balance: I never have to stay late, work on weekends, etc. I get 23 vacation days and my manager encourages me to use them AND completely unplug while away. 

Beautiful office: I work at the new Optum office in Eden Prairie. Building is modern and comfortable. Full size gym and locker room, and workout classes. Great parking ramp with a skyway so you never need to go outside in the rain or snow!

Work from home: VERY progressive with WFH! I can work from wherever I want. if I want to WFH one day, I can. If I want to WFH the whole week, I can do that, too. No one questions you.

Total autonomy

No drama: This is a very heads down place! I can't stress that enough. No one socializes with each other -- most of the time, you never even talk to your cube neighbors (because they're probably working from home). This is a positive for me though -- after working in some high drama offices, this is a refreshing change. 

All meetings are over webex: Great news if you hate in-person meetings like I do -- because there are very few! In the 6 months I've been here, I've had 4 in person meetings. This is also a con because you never meet your coworkers - read the con list for more info. 

30 minute "best practice" meeting times: You will not get invited to 2+ hour meetings, ever. Nearly all meetings are only 30 minutes. You might have the one-off meeting that's an hour, but it's rare. 

Good, standardized PM practices. But some of the documentation requirements are too rigid and can slow progress down. Our group is trying to move to 100% agile. Slowly.... All of my projects so far have been waterfall SDLC. Although as a new person, it would help to have a PM to shadow on some of these documentation/audit practices. I've had to learn as I go. 

- Great cafeteria with cheap prices. I can get a lunch here cheaper than I can bring it from home.

-Very engaging training classes!!! All training classes are over LearnSource (i.e. your computer) but the videos are well done and entertaining.
cons:
-Building seems empty because so many people WFH. It's almost kind of...sad. Such a nice building but no one is there.

-Internet explorer is the browser of choice. Yuck. You have to have special permissions to download Google Chrome or Firefox on your computer.

-If you like socializing with your coworkers, this is NOT a place for you! I can't stress that enough!! You will NOT meet your new BFF here. Everyone is very heads-down and focused on work -- no one chit chats about football or True Detective! You will not have coworkers stopping by your desk (to chat about a TV show OR to even chat about work). Most of my days, I don't talk to anyone in person. It's kind of depressing -- and I'm an introvert! There are no happy hours, social events outside of work, etc (this is a positive for me because I hate that stuff).

-Lots of contractors. Not that it's a bad thing - I've had great experiences with the PM contractors. They obviously don't last as long as the employees, and there's more contractor PMs than employee PMs.

-Difficult, as a new person, to know "who's who." There is no face-to-face meetings, so as a PM, it's tough to know who does what, since there's no face to put with the name. I struggle with this a lot, as I'm not used to this extreme of a "remote" workforce! 

-No wifi for your phone. Wifi is only available for visitors and you must have a user name and password. 

-Nearly all social media websites are blocked. Not really a con, but something you might want to know. You won't be browsing facebook at work!

-LOTS of meetings. Sure, the meetings aren't in person, they're over Webex, but you will have a LOT of them.

-Some "know-it-all" ego-driven coworkers, especially on the tech side. But this is typical of IT in general. I've witnessed this at every org in which I've worked.

review_title: Bait and switch hiring practices (it's a call center)
pros: - Work from home environment (completely) - very diverse - company values look good on paper
cons:
-Ad/job I responded to and interviewed was different than the job I was given. I feel bait and switched. (Call center!!!!) 

- they refer you to useless Learnsources or the Intranet or tell you to talk to management regarding moving up or promotions, but the truth is unless you know someone, they don't want you moving up. You are a number to this company, they will not invest in your growth. Management will not tell you this, and will tell you to look at some pdf documents or something.

-Housecalls program is a call center. Do not let the interview/recruiter person tell you differently. People from my training class quit once they found out. 

-Strict call center metrics (AHT/ACW) etc. Did not want you going to the bathroom unless you were on your scheduled 15 minute break. ( They are begging for OSHA and ADA violations) 

- Micromanaging to the extreme. Every second is tracked, and they have a points system (more than 5 minutes late and you get a partial point etc, if you get 3 points you're in trouble type deal, if you're over your allotted acw time a manager will ping you to ask why, even if the notes take forever to type in) 

- Emergencies are not tolerated, and there is no flexibility with your schedule, good luck getting time off, or having a stable lunch break at the same time every day, it changes daily 

- Lunches are 30 minutes only, and if you get stuck on a call and end up having to go later than your scheduled time, you get in trouble. 

- You are only a warm body to answer phones, there is no upward mobility. 

- benefits suck, which is surprising for an insurance company. High deductible unless you opt for the copay plan and that's an in network only plan (Premiums are ridiculous, and raises are non existent so you end up losing money after your first year employed here if you keep the insurance) plus they have a spouse coverage surcharge of $150 a month

- provided company wifi, however wifi is not fast enough to do your work. 

- hiring process took way too long, and everything was ridiculously complicated (for no good reason) 

- the job they hired for is basic call center, however the ad required 2 separate medical trainings and a set year amount of medical experience. I think they just wanted medically familiar people so they didn't have to train, as I am grossly overqualified. 

-training is different from what you're doing on the floor. Once you start doing live calls, what you learned in training is useless. 

- you will be chained to your desk, as this is back to back phone calls but they will not tell you that in training. 

- pay started at $23 an hour and I'm still at 23 an hour. 

- because of insanely high turnover, I constantly receive emails and requests to refer friends to the position which I would never do because of the gross misleading nature of how I was hired (ew, feels MLM/scammy) 

- can only speak for my department, but we aren't actually doing any good, we are just autodialing people and harassing them for medical information. Half the people are annoyed at how many times we call and the other half of the patients just say what they have to so they can shut us up. 

- the tuition reimbursement kicks in after you work for 6 months but if you leave within 24 months of accepting it (from what I understand) you have to pay it back. Plus it's only like 5k anyway. 

- the software is OLD. It sucks. No seriously, they tell you not to put in tickets to IT because they know the issues, but they don't ever get fixed. Can't save assessments and submit them for 5-6-10 minutes at a time, but if you're in acw for longer than they think is necessary because you're waiting on the assessment to save you're in trouble, even though you can't use the program without saving, so you're set up for failure.

- programs were not properly provisioned even up to the day you are supposed to take phone calls out of training. (Which makes training extra useless since you can't use the programs you are trying to be trained for) 

- my manager is nice, and my co-workers are good people, but my god are the rules here draconian and downright sociopathic. 

- this place squeezes as much productivity as they can get of you, and penalizes you for even 1 minute out of productivity. Have to pee after an hour but break isn't until later? Oh well, have an occurrence for using the bathroom. Doorbell rang and you want to step away for a minute to sign a package? Nope, that'll be trouble for you and not approved. Have a writeup.

 - I applied here because I thought that I would be doing good here, but this place will just grind you down and take whatever productivity they can and threaten your job security until you quit so they don't have to pay unemployment. Whatever buzzwords and things they tell you to get you in the door is a lie. I wish I never applied here, I wish I never went through training and accepted the position and as soon as I find something else, I will wash my hands of this company and never associate with them again. Truly a company that only cares for profits and not for people.

pros: - 1.5X overtime pay - 3 weeks starting vacation - Work from home - flex shift options - pretty easy to take PTO days
cons: - No work/life balance - mandatory OT year round. You will be working 45-50 hours per work, every week, all year. Know this and either accept it and apply or avoid. Do not believe any statement to the contrary, it is intentional and how they run the company hovering at around 1200-1500 hours of mandatory OT every week. The only time they hire more people is when it gets above that and they only hire enough to bring it back down to the numbers I just listed. - you are a number, nothing more. All your meetings and discussions will be about your numbers and how they rank, you are set competitively with all other rphs. Extreme metrics to be met and endless micro managing. If you are fast and accurate you will be okay. Do NOT apply if you know you are kind of slow and like to be super thorough. - pay is low - you will start between 50-55 per hour. Raises are yearly based on your rank 1-5 and a 3 gets 1% raise, a 4 gets 2% and a 5 (which is impossible) gets a 3% - work from home which is convenient and nice but also boring. You have no interaction with team members or anyone else throughout the day. No camraderie, you do your work and sign out. Maybe you will like that. - after training you will be dropped off a cliff. Sink or swim. After training and a 4 week ramp you are expected to hit the same numbers as everyone else. And there is no go-to person for help. Better memorize all those job aids and keep up with the endless procedure changes. If you survive the drop after training you will be okay. - it’s a decent job, monotonous and boring, but not bad, but it’s a terrible company. It’s the epitome of corporate, where they preach patient safety but don’t actually care about it (since overworked rphs make more errors and they never end the OT) and you don’t matter in the slightest as a person.

review_title: Get a job somewhere else.  They probably won't hire you anyway
pros: some nice amenities, gym, on site café, large company would  several *potential*  different areas to grow. They do pay on time also.
cons:
Favorites favorites FAVORITES! HR is not helpful. Hiring managers have their 1 perfect candidate mind, even if the candidate doesn't really fit at all for a position, and they won't consider anyone else. They also FREQUENTLY play favorites within teams in a dept. They get their one or two "model employees" and make a little clique and give them advantages the other employees won't/can't get. also with HR, I've applied to well over 30 different jobs that are a good match for me, my skills and my experience. I usually don't even  get a video interview, let alone get anywhere further along in the interview process to get a fair shot at moving up or moving laterally. 

They also don't pay equitably. They even acknowledge this, but they supposedly make up for it with other areas but they never define exactly what our how. As another reviewer also mentioned, a Fortune 5 company can and should pay better than their competitors. Also in regards to pay, they have WAY too many CEO/ CFO's. Another way they play favorites, how many chief executives do you really need? each one gets $2-5 million a year, and stock options, you can hire a LOT of employees that actually drive your business forward if you don't have so many chief officers. 

Go to Aetna or BC/BS for better pay.

pros: It's a big, well-known company, so it will look good on your resume. Lots of jobs in tech in every discipline I can think of.
cons: IT is a very large organization and employee skill sets are extremely silo'd. You won't be getting experience for multiple disciplines without changing jobs within the organization. You will feel like a small cog in a huge machine - and you are. Layoffs happen quietly every year and I didn't know until my number was up. Once on the outside, I found out about people from two previous years of layoffs. Get your earnings up front and be prepared to leave when your value outstrips the salary you're at. Work from home
Job is not hard
Metrics are reachable

Cannot use ACW so they expect you to leave the member in silence while finishing what should be after call work while on the phone just to end the call after a good 2 minutes of silence. They do give you an automatic 7 seconds if ACW which is just a slap to the face. Just take the 7 seconds away and give us the next call. It barley gives us time to catch our breath from the previous call. 
Drinking water and coffee at my desk for 8 hours, you’re going to have to use the bathroom but, You only get 5 minutes of personal time during the work day, so you cannot keep yourself hydrated if you have to keep going to the bathroom. If you have to poop, good luck finishing within 5 minutes. So basically you cannot use the bathroom during work time.
I’ve been working with UHC for less than a year and as much as I enjoy the work, Im truly considering a new job outside of UHC for these reasons. Im looking for a company that stands besides the needs of their employees and based on these issues alone, I can tell UHC only cares about the work that needs to be done and not their employers. 
30 minute lunches??? Is that even legal?? Lol. It probably is but for real, I have time to make me a sandwich, eat, and hopefully use the bathroom and get back to work. Their rules just seem illogical and again for these reasons, even after telling myself I want to retire from this company cause the work is good and rewarding, I don’t see myself working for a company that doesn’t keep their employees in mind.

pros:
-decent living wage
-plenty of OT if you love to work
-fully remote 
-extremely competent trainer
-diverse team of all ages/backgrounds
cons:
When I got hired, I was told we’d have a six week training course. We were to begin taking live calls during the sixth and final week. 

After 3 weeks of training, my 25 classmates and I were “thrown to the wolves” and had to start taking live calls. Some people started getting the hang of it quickly, while others (like me) had serious issues navigating the script and multiple resources needed to complete calls. 

When we need help, we have to place our (usually upset) customer on hold while we type out the problem via Skype. Leadership sometimes takes way to long to respond with a solution, and it’s usually a vague answer that requires multiple follow up messages. It’s tedious and annoying. 

We are also required to work 5 hours of OT every week which does make for a good money saving opportunity. You’ll just have to ask yourself if you can handle it, and if it’s worth sacrificing your mental health. Speaking of which, the “mental health resources” provided by the company are BS. People need to work fewer hours and have time to breathe between calls. We do not want yoga, sessions with a life coach, or mindfulness minutes.

review_title: Nice benifits, constant corporate restructure, promotion opportunities are not equal
pros: This is a ok workplace.
cons:
I wouldn't stay here long term. When I started I was hired at a higher grade and then when a corporate restructure happened my title was demoted. I got "promoted" back in-line to what I was originally hired at but this was about a year afterwards.

Workload is insane and unmanageable, upper management refuses to hire to handle the workload and would rather have a skeleton crew of burnt out employees. There is no movement in this company unless you are in good with someone or related to someone. They base movement on what your current paygrade is as opposed to what your skills and abilities are and will not let you jump pay grades if they think that you are going to make too much even though you are more than qualified for the job. Benefits package is absolutely horrendous and health insurance does not cover anything. Micromanaging, only pointing out any mistakes you may make as opposed to pointing out things that you have done well, and lack of positive work environment are big issues.

I had put in over a decade of work for this company and new people that were being hired or being hired for dollars per hour more than me.

review_title: Run away if you are under 45 - not kid friendly
pros:
It’s only a good place to be if you have the privilege of working for one of the innovative companies they’ve acquired and are in process of gobbling up. I recommend considering a role outside of the company when you start seeing the culture you love disappear. 

Also, it may be an OK place for those that are done growing their families. Their benefits are designed with 45+ age group in mind. Don’t consider UHG (which includes UHC and Optum) if you are Millennial or below. Their total rewards package is not competitive for you.
cons:
The benefits are horrendous - newsworthy horrendous. Most notably, this NOT a company that supports people wanting to build and grow a family.  As a result, they will continue to have challenges recruiting and retaining those from the talented Millennial generation. Let’s take a look at what I’m calling their family-support benefits:
1.) ALERT- not all of their plans include fertility coverage and even when fertility is covered they require to use their own program, Optum Fertility Solutions. This is a horribly abrasive program that further prolongs someone’s ability to have a child. The program is antiquated and puts up a lot of barriers.
2.) UHG doesn’t create separation between their salaried and hourly employees when it comes to benefits. There is not an option to receive 100% of pay while out on Short Term Disability for having a child. You can buy up from 60% to 80% for a great deal of money. I paid over $1,000 for an additional 20% of pay and guess what, I won’t be using the benefit this year. Companies have already noted salaries in their books for the entire year, which means it would cost them NO money to institute salary continuation for their salary employees. This isn’t offered at UHG.
3.) Paid parental leave is only 6 weeks. They recently increased this from 4 weeks. Guys, you can go be an hourly Amazon employee and receive 20 weeks of fully paid parental leave. 6 weeks is insulting. 
4.) While on leave you don’t get paid holidays!!!! If you don’t submit PTO for holidays, such as Christmas, you won’t be paid!! << this is one of the most ludicrous practices I’ve ever seen. 

Don’t let them tell you this is what benefits are like at all large insurance carriers. That is not true. I know for a fact the Blues and Cigna are far more generous here. UHG doesn’t use consultants to help with their benefits strategy and it appears they also don’t leverage benchmarking. Either that, or they don’t care. Likely a combination of both. While I enjoy my role within the company, I will be leaving due to the benefits.

Do not accept a position in sales until you ask about GOAL ADJUSTMENTS 
“Goal Adjustments” This is when the pay you less in commissions after you already made the sale. When you about to receive your commissions they tell you how successful certain marketing was or whatnot, so they are going to have to adjust your goal since you had more opportunities to make a sale.  This is quite possibly illegal. It’s definitely unethical.
You will make in the 30s as a good salesman.  Maybe 40s if you are a wizard on the phone. Also, goal adjustments are NOT rare and the happen multiple times a year.
Run folks, run for the hills. Illegal practices management that does not care.

review_title: Big Company, Not great for Low Level Workers
pros: Work from home. 401K, but no matching until year 2. Health insurance (but high deductible) and definitely average. Better than nothing. Huge company with a lot of opportunity for those who will pursue it.
cons:
1. There is no flexibility in this job. 

You are tied to your computer all day with two breaks and lunch. There are no part time options, and after shift bid, your shift is your shift. You must clock in and out exactly on the minute for every task that you perform. They force you to turn on your computer in advance of the workday to be logged in at exactly the start of your shift, which is apparently legal because they give you paid breaks. 

2. Every single thing you do is tracked. 

They use a system to track your activities and metrics, and measure your adherence but it doesn't work, and they still tell you that you have to be 95% compliant (with the faulty software). They won't correct it either, even when it's wrong. They send your adherence report with the errors with that same note that you should be at 95%. All of your calls are recorded. You are evaluated on your calls on a monthly basis. All day long the team lead hounds you to tell you if your "after call work" is too many seconds, and the software will pop up with annoying messages that you have placed a member on hold many times while you are trying to resolve a difficult problem. This is supposed to be helpful, but it isn't. It's like having a mosquito buzzing you and biting you all day long. Some problems are very difficult, involve many phone calls, and require the member to be placed on hold. Everyone knows this.

3. Toxic positivity rules. 

There is a culture of "pretending" in which you must pretend everything is great, even when you are not given the information and resources to do your job. If you question anything you will be considered a troublemaker. Top down organization. If you want to be promoted, grin , pretend, and do the work. Often times a change will be implemented, and there are errors with the change. Instead of fixing the errors, leadership will suggest workarounds that simply lead to other problems. 

4. The environment is extremely negative. 

You are threatened with being fired for being just one minute late, but you are expected to take calls and work late if you have to. So if you get a call at 4:59 you have to take it or you could get fired. In meetings corrective action plans will be discussed, and how to not get fired is a frequent topic. Also your metrics will be displayed in public so everyone knows if you are meeting the required metrics. 

5. The metrics are faulty and the small bonuses are hard to get. 

You are evaluated on metrics that are highly questionable and subject to chance. Some of these metrics clearly lack face-validity, are not appropriately targeted to gather relevant data, and have negative unintended consequences with respect to their implementation. If one person gives you a bad survey in a month because they are mad about their late enrollment penalty that you cannot fix you won't get your tiny little bonus even if you worked your tail off all month and you are a well respected and appreciated advocate. Management doesn't care if you got 20 surveys and 17 of them were all tens. The two angry people will mean that you don't meet the threshhold for a bonus and you won't get it. 

6. You can't schedule or take PTO with ease. 

It is Impossible to take PTO because they seem to always be understaffed. As soon as you think maybe you have enough staff, they'll start moving people around until you have call after call and there won't be any PTO. If you quit, they won't pay unused PTO (depending on state law) because they say it is a "grant." So they won't let you take it when you work or when you quit. While the company makes billions, they want all the call center workers to use their PTO when it is slow, and won't let employees secure dates for family vacations far in advance or even promise that they can take them months (or even a year) in advance. They open a vacation window in May or June for the last six months of the year, and then everyone jumps in there to try to get the days off they need. But only a couple of people can take a single day off, and often there are no days you can take off at all in the next three months. Of course, opening up the window so late means you can't buy plane tickets far in advance or even count on being able to take that vacation at all. If you can't get the days, they won't help you and you'll have to take "occurrences" which could result in you being fired. There is not even any way to go to the doctor without a strike against you. 

The low level customer service managers are just trying to get promoted to the next level, so they won't address the systemic issues and general lack of respect provided to these essential call center workers who are the heart of the business. They want their metrics to be the best so they can get the next promotion. They just tell you to "be positive."

review_title: Horrible Place To Work!!  Recruiters BEWARE!
job_title: Manager, Talent Acquisition in Eden Prairie, MN
pros: They allow you to work from home to look for a new job.
cons:
I am micromanaged down to the second by the poor leadership in this company. This forces me to micromanage the recruiters that report into me. 

Just as has been reported (Federal Judge) we put the bottom line before not only our patients but our workers as well. Our people lie under oath to try and keep us out of trouble on some of these things. 

Just like we discriminate against our patients we also discriminate against new hires. Our algorithms in our software are designed that way. Whites are favored. 

We stifle our competition simply because of our size. 

The Talent Acquisition leadership bullies its recruiters. It is a very hostile work environment. 

Turnover at the company as a whole is tremendously high which should explain a lot. 

More layoffs are coming.

As much as we say we are diverse, this is not reflected in our hiring practices. This has been proven. 

Our ATS is archaic and adds to the recruiters frustration and is part of their overall dissatisfaction with their own jobs. At Optum we work much harder than necessary with our own red tape.
It takes a ton of people to get anything or anyone hired. 

We have a lot of poor quality hires. If we hire anyone good they just leave. We have to fill the vacancies somehow? 

We use metrics to intimidate our recruiters and staff. 

The work and justifications that go into trying to hire someone are unreal. The recruiters are forced to literally dictate during interviews to justify a hire. 

Just like the products we sell, our own insurance is very expensive and pays out very little. They force you to see Optum doctors who are also not happy working at UHG. Unfortunately their care and the service we receive from these doc in a box shops is subpar and the care they give is reflective of that.

Want proof of any of this? Just Google it! Stay away!

review_title: Great place to build a career but YOU own your success
pros: UHG is an amazing company with a tremendous impact on nearly every aspect of the healthcare industry thanks to solid leadership, a talented and dedicated work force, a great mission, and lots of possibilities to build your career in many areas over a long period of time. Generally, UHG supports a flexible work environment (hours, PTO), etc.
cons: Frequent reorganizations are common and often disrupt precious progress employees make over several months or more building a relationship with their manager. Just when you build rapport and demonstrate value, you may be realigned to a new manager who resets the clock on any progress you thought you were making at advancing your career. At UHG, you own your career, and with few exceptions, do not expect a promotion unless you formally take on a new role. Higher salaries and grade levels don't get handed out on a silver platter at UHG, even if you think (and are told) that you have a great relationship with your manager and perform well. If you value and seek vertical career growth, you must not sit back and wait for it to come your way, because it probably won't unless and until you move onto a new role.

job_title: Sales Development Representative in Phoenix, AZ
pros: The company has great benefits, health insurance, dental, and 401k
cons:
They will sell you on this position saying they will help develop you professionally and boost you into a strong career. The fact of the matter is that this is an 18 month "sales development program" for recent graduates and in my 12 months there the "development" I received was next to none. They train you on what medicare and insurance is and then put you on the phones 8 hours a day. You're speaking to uninformed and uneducated medicare customers who will yell and scream at you. I left because I didn't want to sell insurance over the phone for the rest of my life which was what most people ended up doing. Additionally the pay is not good. Keep in mind I was over 180% to sales goal during all periods and I barely broke $50,000. I had plenty of friends there who were to goal or under and made less then $35,000. I only took this job because I graduated during a global pandemic and no one was hiring. If you have any other options DO NOT TAKE THIS JOB! 

Also from September-December expect to work 70+ hours a week for AEP.

review_title: Reactive company that does not invest in developing and retaining their talent
pros:
Job security. 
The company operates in a matured, regulated market with strong ties to the government.
cons:
I resigned from UHG in 2021. This healthcare behemoth operates in a regulated, matured industry with limited competitors.

At the beginning of the pandemic, I asked my leaders when UHG would align with other organizations and shift to WFH, my question was laughed at by my leaders. 3 weeks later, we moved to WFH to follow state and CDC guidelines.

In September 2020, UHG mandated its employees with no underlying conditions or living with someone with U.C. to return to office.

Since I did not have an underlying condition nor lived with anyone with one, I had to return to the office in the middle of a pandemic. By doing so, I could not visit my mother who did not live with me but have underlying conditions. Later the return to office initiative backfired and UHG asked employees to return to WFH.

There were so many other things that made this origination a bad fit for me, but the above was what pushed me to resign a year later. UHG does not proactively look after its employees well being.

pros: I'm a bit torn on which way this review should go.  I had a lot of positive of experiences at UnitedHealth and was offered a lot of opportunities including merit based promotions.  In my division at least, we looked internally for talent and promoted within.  Work life balance was respected quite a bit as well.  There were definitely 60+ hour weeks, but to offset that, it was not an issue to run out in the middle of the day for a school event or what not.  Pay and benefits were on the average to slightly above side of things for the Minneapolis area. I also worked with a very talented group of people which is not always the norm at previous companies.
cons: My main issue with UnitedHealth was their willingness to use someone up until they're done and toss them out.  As a manager/director I went through a couple rounds of layoffs which seemed to be a good way to get rid of the squeaky wheel, not necessarily dead weight.  Towards the end of my tenure I became that squeaky wheel because of the unethical work I saw going on and it was obvious I was on the way out.

review_title: Depends how you look at it
job_title: Research Consultant (Lewin Group/OptumServe Consulting) in Falls Church, VA
pros:
Lewin/OSC offers a gentle introduction to the consulting world and a decent work/life balance (can depend on your project and supervisor). 

Generally, immediate coworkers are kind and smart. I've heard some horror stories about managers, but my experience has been alright.

If you advocate for yourself you can get additional responsibilities and potentially more interesting work, otherwise prepare to do mundane tasks regularly. This mundanity is a big Pro for some, and can allow you to focus energy on non-work things.

If you're healthy and young, you can look past a lot of the drawbacks of working here if you keep your time horizon brief. Many people spend a year or two here, and use it as a stepping stone to then go on to grad school or a better consulting firm.
cons:
Could you imagine being part of the largest healthcare company (Lewin is owned by UnitedHealth), and receiving garbage healthcare benefits? My new insurance is 30% less than the price of the lowest cost high-deductible UHC offering, and it has no deductible. My max out-of-pocket is a fraction of what it was while at Lewin. I am thrilled to get the medical procedures I've been holding off on due to costs.

It's mind-boggling that a company that claims to care so much about health, does so little to improve the health of their employees. 

And it's not like it's they can't. This company has a massive budget, especially when it comes to stock buyback programs, but caring about employees beyond the bare minimum? No, sorry, they only make changes related to employees to "be competitive" with other companies, whatever that means (leadership said they’d share their research on how Lewin's “competitive” compensation rates were determined, but never did). Bummer that your cost of living has skyrocketed the past couple of years, best they can do is an annual 1.5% salary increase. Your healthcare premium, that is provided through them, will be increasing by 10% though.

Don't get me started about mediocre maternity/paternity leave, touting 21 days of PTO despite it actually also encompassing sick days, pay that is far below competitors, sad bonus structure, tuition reimbursement that hardly covers any tuition, no transparency, etc...

If you view Lewin as part of the larger organization, and what they could provide employees versus what they choose to provide employees, you might hate it. And this is completely aside from the ethics of coming up with new and innovative ways to profit off of people's medical debt (or, as they call it, "Fintech”).

Some will say "well, that's just the parent company, not Lewin", and they're kind of right. No matter what though, the leaders of the larger organization will have full management of Lewin, and that is a Con.

Also, leadership has chosen to not share financial performance and their annual employee wellness survey results, which they typically share, so take that how you will.

pros: Opportunity for growth. The pay isn’t terrible. Overtime offered frequently.
cons:
The work/life balance is terrible. They would add overtime the same day and then tell you, “this is a call center, you need to be able to be added to any shift at any time.” Which would be fine with some notice, but I can’t get to work and then notice I have to stay until 8pm and try to scramble to find a babysitter or reschedule things. 
In training we were told there was a department we could call to assist us when we couldn’t find an answer or needed help, once we were out of training we were told to not call them and that calls to them were tracked, which impacted performance. 
The day I got out of training, we were cross trained for only 3 hours to another department, then basically left to fail at that department. It was overwhelming and when we raised concerns that we were unprepared they said, “Just sound confident. This is a call center.” I just felt like it was more than a “call center” when your dealing with someone’s healthcare and insurance. It was frustrating to feel like my concerns were not addressed. Management didn’t care if we were drowning and unprepared, they only cared about how many calls we could take, whether we gave correct information or not. I was told to “just sound confident, so members don’t call back within the next two days to impact our numbers and stats.” It was frustrating to feel like I couldn’t help our members.
Insurance was terrible, only high deductible plans offered.
I just left this company feeling like they care more about profit and call stats, than MEMBERS and employee knowledge and confidence.

job_title: Manager Customer Service in Overland Park, KS
pros:
PTO is generous; however, per the employee handbook, it is considered a GIFT, not a BENEFIT.

Sadly, I can't think of anything else
cons:
PTO is a GIFT, not a benefit (per the employee handbook). Once you give notice, you cannot take the remaining PTO and be paid.

As management, HR does not support the management; the jail is run by the inmates.

Overall benefits are average to mediocre, especially considering it's a major insurer, and pharmacy benefits management company

OptumRx customer service side of the business does not in any site except one, display compassion for their employees. They expect the front-line advocates to change their schedules and lives on a flip of a dime, based on business needs. If you don't volunteer, they have a process of voluntold. If you are unable to accommodate the voluntold, you will get corrective action in the form of a point.

It was not uncommon to award 1-2 cent per hour raises to front-line advocates. Yes, some received more. The point is raises are inadequate considering their responsibilities.

Lots of favoritism at all levels. More so than other companies I've worked for. There is always some, but this was blatant. 

All levels through directors are not treated well. Calls all hours throughout the night. They have poor processes that are not mature and considering their longevity one would believe that they would no longer operate as a start-up.

job_title: Director, Operations Management in Minneapolis, MN
pros: Working at UnitedHealth Group does not mean you'll just be paying insurance claims. Its fairly easy to get exposure and experience in a variety of fields. I have noticed a large difference in pay from one group to the next; some areas --- and by area I don't mean job title I mean the division--pays really well and others under pay and over work their staff. Hard work is recognized and rewarded in most divisions. The company offers a lot in the way of personal/career development opportunities.
cons: Although the workforce is majority female it is still a male dominated company. As you move to the top of the hierarchy. For example: the CEO has 13 direct reports 10 are male 3 are female; one of which is the executive assistant. Another con is that the company has discovered its easier to lay off people than it is to have meaningful conversations about performance issues, and allow a person to fix their issues. The result is 2 things...others without performance issues are required to pick up the slack of the person falling down until that person is "layed-off" and then its another 6 months before an adequate replacement can be found. The other issue is that people sometimes simply don't know they are falling down. Give them a chance to change.

pros: The only pros about this job was that it was a fully remote / work from home position and my coworkers were nice (I actually still keep in touch with them to this day!)
cons:
Disclaimer: I haven't worked at Optum / UnitedHealth Group since the Summer of 2021. Hopefully a lot of these policies have changed for the better, but the following is my personal and true experience with the company.

I worked in the BAR (Benefits, Authorizations, and Referrals) department for mental health. I would take calls from members and providers on a variety of issues. There were back to back calls, which was to be expected, but we had very little time to ourselves. The ACW (after call work) average was 45 seconds. They only wanted us to spend 45 seconds after a call to finish our notes and catch our breaths before going back into the queue. Are you serious?

The calls were very triggering, too. I remember getting calls from people threatening to harm themselves and others. We aren't crisis managers; we aren't trained to handle suicidal people and the fact that it was our responsibility to make sure that they got to the right place (often with a long hold time), it put a lot of unfair pressure on us.

We were only allowed a 30 minute lunch, and I believe that we should have at least 45 minutes to an hour to recharge after taking calls nonstop for four hours. We were also allowed two 15 minute breaks, but if we went over it by a minute, there would be managers asking us what the problem was.

Their PTO / Holiday agreement was awful. I'm not sure if this was limited to only CSRs, but if we wanted to get holiday pay, we'd have to work the day before AND the day after the holiday. Let's say it's Memorial Day weekend, and you want to take the Friday before it off. Well, you won't be getting paid for that Monday! God forbid people want to have an extra day off to spend with their family or just to relax without being penalized for it.

The turnover rate was very high. People were quitting this job before the training was even over! By the time I left, half of my training class had quit. And now, less than a year later, none of the people that I trained with currently work at that position anymore. You would think the higher ups at UHG would notice it and realize the common denominator.

There was also more responsibility for the same pay. During my final two weeks at the position, I heard from my coworkers that they were going to be trained in claims which would mean taking on an additional set of callers, but their pay would not be increased. 

The health insurance wasn't good. How are we working at one of the largest health insurance companies and the options that they offer their employees are trash?! Some people weren't able to afford the insurance at all because the pay was so low. I was able to get the most expensive insurance, but that still came with a high deductible.

I could go on for much longer, but I, along with my coworkers, was so eager to leave this job. If any management is reading this, please see my advice below.

review_title: Your job really depends on the Supervisor you get
job_title: Outbound Customer Service Representative in Roanoke, VA
pros:
- Good PTO, easy to take time off
-Systems are pretty straightforward and easy to use (besides old DOS systems)
- You have support if you need it on a call 
-Most of the people you talk too are alright
cons: My first boss was a godsend he was very helpful if you ever needed help would always be available, gave great constructive criticism and would make sure you felt comfortable in your role. He would always reach out if something seemed wrong to make sure you were ok and taken care of and would take your side if something went wrong and truly advocated for his team. I was switched teams to another Supervisor who consistently micromanaged you for every little thing never giving praise for doing good work only hearing what you did bad. Most sups have team favorites and if you aren't one you too will be micromanaged and made to feel like you aren't doing enough even if you do hit your metrics and when you don't they will try to get you out the door. I was consistently belittled by a sup, even for a good call, about things I did wrong in a non constructive manner. It was always "Sure, they gave you a good score but.." and they would rail into me about things I could have done for a superior experience. If a member called in and was upset, whether it be for hold time, being transferred, upset about a bill, ect. if they give you a bad score no matter how hard you tried to help it was your fault because no matter what 'you can always turn the call around'. I was told "normally we don't keep people if they get a below meets expectations" on a performance review for the year as a threat. Was consistently told that we need to do good because the sup is reviewed and received bonuses based off our metrics and if we didn't do good it wasn't because we needed help it was because we didn't care enough. A coworker wasn't doing the best but trying and instead of coaching and helping get better in other terms was told she would probably need to search for a new job. My team was threatened that if we didn't keep ACW (after call work) down she would quit doing the paperwork to get our bonuses and micromanage our ACW even if you averaged 70 seconds and the meets metric at least 30 seconds higher. Sup didn't know how to help us with our roles and was told "I don't have to know, I'm a manger to manage you guys not take phone calls." but the sup was the one to grade your calls. I, like a few others who were switched to this team, finally left UHC. I had anxiety about coming to work I felt degraded and every time I received a message from my sup had a mini heart attack wondering what I did wrong this time even when I was doing the best I could. This job really isn't hard and can be laid back and rewarding when you can truly help the member. If you like to help people and are friendly you'll do just fine but the manager can make or break your experience.
